did.unittitle: American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology Records, 1923-2015

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology

physdesc.label: Quantity
physdesc.extent: plus additions of 6 cubic ft. (6 boxes)

extref.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Archives Department

did.abstract: Records of a Milwaukee-based professional medical organization. Formed in 1943 from the merger of the Society for the Study of Asthma and Allied Conditions and the American Association for the Study of Allergy, the organization was originally named the American Academy of Allergy (AAA); in 1982 the name changed to the American Academy of Allergy & Immunology (AAAI); the current name, the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (AAAAI) was adopted in 1995. Records exist in the collection from the two predecessor organizations, though the bulk of the materials, including photographs and textual records, are from the AAA, the AAAI and the AAAAI.

bioghist.p: The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology was formed by the merger of the American Association for the Study of Allergy and the Association for the Study of Asthma and Allied Conditions. A group of West Coast and Midwest physicians formed the American Association for the Study of Allergy in 1923 and the group became known as the Western Society. In 1924, New York physicians interested in allergy met and formed the Society for the Study of Asthma and Allied Conditions; this group became known as the Eastern Society. When the Western and Eastern Societies merged in December 1943, the new association was named the American Academy of Allergy. The executive office was established in Milwaukee in 1948. In 1982, the name was changed to the American Academy of Allergy and Immunology and in 1995 to the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology.

scopecontent.p: Scope and content notes of each series are provided in the contents list.

arrangement.p: This collection was received in, and is organized in, multiple parts. Additional materials have not been physically or intellectually arranged and interfiled, and researchers may need to consult more than one part of the collection to locate similar materials.
The records are arranged into the following series:

item.ref: Executive Committee and Board of Directors

Audio-Visual Materials
Videocassettes and Film
Audio Cassettes and Digital Audio Files
Photographs
Oral History Interviews of the Oral History Project for the AAAAI
Artifacts from the History of Asthma Treatment

arrangement.p: Within series 7, audio cassettes are housed in boxes 391-403, 497, 523, 528-531, and 542. Videocassettes are housed in boxes 408-414 and 497. Photographs are housed in boxes 330-334, 430, and 441

item.ref: Accession 2013-038: Publications and Annual Meeting Materials, 1997-2013

otherfindaid.p: Finding aid for accession 2015-035 available in the Archives.

accessrestrict.p: Restrictions on access are noted in the contents lists. If no restrictions are noted, the materials are open to all members of the public in accordance with state law.

userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of libel, privacy, and copyright which may be involved in the use of this collection (Wisconsin Statutes 19.21-19.39).

acqinfo.p: The agreement between the AAAAI and UWM was executed in October 1998. Due to the high number of accessions received by the Archives Department on a regular basis, detailed information about accessions is not given on this finding aid but is available upon request.

processinfo.p: Detailed information about processing is not given on this finding aid, but is available upon request.

processinfo.head: Preservation Information
processinfo.p: On June 15, 2013, electronic files from CDs 49, 51, and 52 were migrated onto network storage as disk image files [.iso]. Researchers must still use the original CD access copies.
In August 2015, Ashlie Biddle and Phyllis Reske updated the finding aid to reflect the incorporation of Accession 2014-05 into the collection.
On October 20, 2015, electronic files from CDs (some of which had been in box 741) were migrated onto the Archives' hard drive. These files will be used as alternative access points.

George Blood L.P digitized the oral history audio cassette recordings in February 2016. Audio preservation master files were created as 96 kHz/24-bit resolution 2 channel broadcast .wav files. Audio access copies were created as 44 kHz/192 kbps bit rate 2 channel .mp3 files.

phystech.p: As of January 2017 electronic files were accessible on a Intel Core i5-4570 CPU (3.20 GHz, 4 GB RAM) running Windows 7, with Service Pack 1. Major exceptions for accessible files are some of the programs used to provide embedded access to poster abstracts and educational programs, many of which were designed for Windows 3.1 or earlier and do not function properly on modern systems. The Archives has made the PDFs of the abstracts and articles themselves available where possible in these cases. The software is being preserved in binary format in the event that the Archives acquires the technology to make this software usable. Software used to access the files includes Windows Picture and Fax Viewer, Google Chrome, Windows Media Player, Adobe Reader XI, and Microsoft Office Suite 2007.
The collection includes records in the following file formats:
The executable files for the catalog abstracts must be run from the access CDs.

did.unittitle: 1. Executive Committee and Board of Directors, 1944-2015

scopecontent.p: The bulk of this series consists of agenda books containing agendas of annual and interim meetings of the executive committee, reports by officers and committees, and minutes. Correspondence is included in this series, the bulk of which is between the executive committee and other committees. Correspondence files from past officers are also included.
Beginning with November 2005, Board of Directors Meeting Agenda and Division Agenda books are filed together.

did.unittitle: Agenda and Supplemental Reference Material, January 2006

scopecontent.p: This series contains materials from annual meetings, as well as pre- and post-meetings.

scopecontent.p: Subseries includes materials distributed as the scientific sessions of the annual meeting. Materials are arranged chronologically and thereafter alphabetically by session title or numerically by session number. Researchers should consult the annual meeting programs for listings of sessions.

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence and related information on the Academy's relationship with organizations that work within the fields of allergy, asthma, and immunology. Much information can be found regarding the American Board of Allergy and Immunology, American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, and the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America.

separatedmaterial.p: This series was returned to the AAAAI in October 2009.

scopecontent.p: Included in this series are photographs, including annual meeting, past president and Board of Directors photographs. Also included are videocassettes of annual meetings, as well as productions sponsored by the AAAI. Most of the CDs, DVDs, and beta tapes are audio only. Audio cassettes contain continuing education courses sponsored by the AAAI and the AAAAI, as well as recordings of paper presentations at annual meetings. Most audio cassettes are recording of sessions presented at annual meetings. Boxes 728 and 730 include a paper index that describes the contents of the audio cassettes from boxes 728 and 730.

arrangement.p: Audio cassettes are housed in boxes 391-403, 497, 523, 528-531, 542, and 728-733. Videocassettes are housed in boxes 408-414 and 497. Photographs are housed in boxes 330-334, 430, and 441.

scopecontent.p: A variety of general information regarding the Academy's operation can be found in this series, including annual reports, membership directories, pollen and spore reports, and press releases. This series also contains position statements, and sample books, which include published materials, such as letterhead, pre-registration materials from annual meetings, invitations, seminar brochures, and newsletters.

scopecontent.p: The Associates are spouses and friends of the members of the AAAAI. This series contain meeting minutes, press clippings, membership directories, information about scholarship programs, and fundraising activities by the Associates.

unittitle.expan: Patient Education for Asthma and Allergy Knowledge

did.unittitle: American Society of Association Executives Award, 1998
12. Oral History Interviews of the Oral History Project for the AAAAI, 2000-2002

bioghist.p: Interviews conducted by Sarah Filzen from 2000 to 2002.

scopecontent.p: Past presidents and prominent members of the AAAAI discuss major events and shifts in AAAAI's history, the impact that AAAAI has had on the profession, and the changing roles and perceptions of allergy in the medical field.

accessrestrict.p: Per the AAAAI Board of Directors, access to the oral histories is restricted for the lifetime of each interview subject. Researchers interested in accessing these interviews should consult the AAAAI archivist, who will work with the AAAAI office to determine if they are open for research. Researchers that have gained permission must use digital access copies for the audio records.

scopecontent.p: The series contains historical material, primarily from parent organizations of the AAAAI. Included are Sheldon Cohen's files for AAA's 25th Anniversary, which provides background for the AAAAI.
